'''''El hobito''''' was the first translation into Spanish of [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]'s ''[[The Hobbit]]''. It was published in [[1964]] in Argentina.<ref>{{HM|AH}}, p. 395</ref>

==History==

On [[3 July]] [[1962]], [[Alina Dadlez]] sent Tolkien a copy of letter from the Argentinian publisher Compañia General Fabril Editora, concerning a Spanish translation of ''The Hobbit''. Tolkien [[Letter to Alina Dadlez (20 July 1962)|replied]] on 20 July to Dadlez, sending her comments about how to translate specific words — suggesting the form ''hobitos'' for ''[[hobbits]]''. Dadlez forwarded Tolkien's comments to the publisher in Argentina, and wrote to Tolkien again on 17 September: the publishers point out that since ''h'' is mute in Spanish, perhaps the form ''jobitos'' could be used. Tolkien [[Letter to Alina Dadlez (19 September 1962)|replied]] on 19 September, saying that he still prefers ''hobitos'': "I am sure many hobbits drop their ''h''s like most rural folk in England".<ref>{{CG|C}}, pp. 594, 598</ref>

''El hobito'' was apparently not very successful since only one edition was published. A second Spanish translation did not appear until 1982 (''El Hobbit'', published by Minotauro).<ref name=TL>{{webcite|author=[[Pieter Collier]]|articleurl=http://www.tolkienlibrary.com/press/1098-a-generous-gift-signed-the-hobbit.php|articlename=A generous gift - the tale behind a signed copy of ''El Hobito''|dated=|website=TL|accessed=25 August 2013}}</ref>
[[File:El hobito - Inscribed by Tolkien.jpg|thumb|left|Tolkien's inscription in ''El hobito''.]]
Tolkien received a few copies of ''El hobito'' from the publisher in Argentina, and apparently gave one to his wife [[Edith Tolkien|Edith]]. A copy is known to have been signed by Tolkien on the title page, including a dedication in Spanish: "para Edita querida R" ("to [my] dear Edith[,] R[onald]"<!-- Freely translated by User:Morgan -->). After Tolkien's death, his eldest son Father [[John Tolkien]] gave the book to Father Antonio Quevedo in September 1973.<ref name=TL/>

==From the back==

Las páginas de este libro tienen la magia y el particular sabor de las antiguas sagas escandinavas. Hermanado con las obras de Swift, Bunyan y Lewis Caroll ... ''El hobito'' señala la plenitud creadora de J.R.R. Tolkien.<ref name=UAN>{{webcite|author=|articleurl=http://uan.nu/dti/hobito.html|articlename=El Hobito argentino: Comentario sobre la primera traducción de The Hobbit|dated=|website=[http://uan.nu/dti/traduc.html Universidad Autónoma de Númenor: Departamento de Traducción Irreverente]|accessed=25 August 2013}}</ref>

[Translation: "The pages of this book contain the magic and the peculiar flavour of the ancient Norse sagas. Related to the works of Swift, Bunyan, and Lewis Carroll ... ''El hobito'' shows the full creativity of J.R.R. Tolkien."<!-- Freely translated by User:Morgan -->]
